scenes.on_screen_action: Fast zoom-in on narrator text: BIG QUESTION. Split-screen: left shows Distracted Boyfriend meme. Boyfriend looking away at "Neural nets (popular)" while girlfriend labelled "Want an expert system?" looks annoyed. Right side: flashing title card: "Meet CLIPS in 30s" with a countdown ticker (00:30). Quick whip-pan to terminal window ready for CLIPS commands.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Want to build an expert system? Meet CLIPS — rule-based, object-oriented, procedural — in 30 seconds. Ready? Go!
scenes.on_screen_text:
Want an expert system?
Distracted Boyfriend: Neural nets (popular) vs CLIPS rules (practical)
Hook: "Want to build an expert system? Meet CLIPS in 30s."

scenes.on_screen_action: Smash-cut to Drake Hotline Bling meme panels. Top (reject) shows nested if/else spaghetti code. Bottom (accept) shows simple CLIPS rule snippet with glowing check. Quick text bullets fly in from the right describing paradigms.
scenes.dialogue_vo: CLIPS is multiparadigm: rules, objects, and procedures. Instead of tangled if/else, you write declarative rules that match facts.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Reject: nested if/else
Accept: simple CLIPS rules
CLIPS = Rule-based + OO + Procedural

scenes.on_screen_action: Animated infographic: Facts flow into Rules → Agenda → Run → Fired Rules. Use Expanding Brain meme on the right showing levels: If/else → Switch/case → Rule-based → Deftemplates + deffacts. Pulsing arrows show forward-chaining direction.
scenes.dialogue_vo: CLIPS uses forward-chaining: start with facts, match rules, put activated rules on the agenda, then run to fire them and derive new facts.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Forward-chaining:
Facts → Rules → Agenda → Run → Fired Rules
Expanding Brain: If/else → Switch → Rule-based → Deftemplates+deffacts

scenes.on_screen_action: Show a terminal window typing a deftemplate. Animate a 'fact' token popping into a vertical fact-list UI when asserted. Meme sticker: 'Deftemplates decoded — see a rule match in 20s'.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Facts are chunks of info: a relation name with slots. Define their shape with deftemplate, then assert facts into the engine.
scenes.on_screen_text:
deftemplate = structure for facts
Code:
(deftemplate patient
  (slot name)
  (slot temp)
)

Example assert:
(assert (patient (name "John") (temp 39)))

scenes.on_screen_action: Terminal shows deffacts block being typed and saved. Then narrator types (reset) and the initial facts appear in the fact-list. Overlay tip bubble: 'deffacts = initial knowledge'.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Use deffacts to assert a bundle of initial knowledge. Reset clears the environment and re-asserts those deffacts.
scenes.on_screen_text:
deffacts = initial facts
Code:
(deffacts initial-facts
  (patient (name "John") (temp 37))
  (patient (name "Mary") (temp 40))
)

Commands:
(reset)  ; clear and assert deffacts

scenes.on_screen_action: Animated rule card flips in, header on top, LHS patterns on left, RHS actions on right. Use caption 'Rule = pattern match → action' with Drake meme small overlay. Show code for a fever rule with pattern and printout action.
scenes.dialogue_vo: A rule has a header, LHS conditional elements to match facts, and RHS actions to execute when fired. Simple and declarative.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Rule structure:
(defrule header
  (LHS patterns)
  =>
  (RHS actions)
)

Example:
(defrule fever-rule
  (patient (name ?n) (temp ?t&:(> ?t 38)))
  =>
  (printout t "Alert: " ?n " has a fever." crlf)
)

scenes.on_screen_action: Cut to terminal. Type (watch facts) in one pane. In another pane type an assert of a new patient fact. Animated ping sound and a rule card leaps onto an 'Agenda' column. Overlay: 'Watch one assert make rules jump onto the agenda.'
scenes.dialogue_vo: Pro tip: use (watch facts) to see facts being asserted or retracted. When an assert matches a rule pattern, that rule is activated and put on the agenda.
scenes.on_screen_text:
(watch facts)
(assert (patient (name "Sam") (temp 40)))

Watch output (example):
==> f-3     (patient (name Sam) (temp 40))
==> Activation: fever-rule  (on agenda)

Hook: "Watch one assert make rules jump onto the agenda."

scenes.on_screen_action: Terminal types (run). Animated fireworks as the rule fires and printout appears. Show a small 'Surprised Pikachu' reaction when the printout shows 'Alert: Sam has a fever.' Then show the fact-list updated if RHS asserts/modifies facts.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Hit (run) and CLIPS fires rules from the agenda. The RHS actions execute — printing, asserting, modifying, or retracting facts.
scenes.on_screen_text:
(run)

Output:
Alert: Sam has a fever.

Summary: run = execute fired rules from the agenda

scenes.on_screen_action: Quick montage: modify, retract commands typed. On the left, an animated 'This Is Fine' dog appears when a contradicting fact exists; then narratively show retracting the wrong fact and modifying another. The fact-list updates with watch messages.
scenes.dialogue_vo: To change facts use (modify), to remove them use (retract). If facts contradict, don't panic — retract or modify, or reset to reload deffacts. Watch shows every change.
scenes.on_screen_text:
(modify 3 (temp 37))    ; change fact #3's temp
(retract 2)              ; remove fact #2

Watch output example:
==> Retracted: f-2
==> Modified: f-3

Tip: use (reset) to reassert deffacts

scenes.on_screen_action: Show pattern-matching animation: a variable ?n grabs the name from a fact and ?$rest swallows extra fields. Side-by-side code vs instant match visualization. Add a small Two Buttons (Sweating Guy) meme: 'Write control flow' vs 'Write declarative rules' with the button 'Pick rules' highlighted.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Use variables to capture values in patterns — e.g., ?name. Use multi-field variables like $?rest to match variable-length fields. Use anonymous/wildcard patterns when you don't need the value.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Variables & wildcards:
- ?name  => single-field variable
- $?rest => multi-field variable
- wildcard = match without binding

Example:
(patient (name ?n) (symptoms $?s))
=> ?n captures the name, $?s captures any symptoms

scenes.on_screen_action: Zoom out to show an 'Agenda' panel filling up with activated rules. Animated checklist shows rules being fired one-by-one when (run) is executed. Overlay: 'Facts → agenda → fired rules — watch CLIPS do it.' Finish with Expanding Brain meme reiterating the power of rule-based systems.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Remember: patterns matching facts activate rules onto the agenda. Run executes them in order (conflict resolution can reorder), producing new facts or actions — that's the CLIPS loop.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Facts → Agenda → Fired Rules
(agenda shows activated rules)
(run)  => rules fire
Note: CLIPS has conflict-resolution strategies to pick which activation fires next

scenes.on_screen_action: Rapid-fire command cheat-sheet slides fly by: assert, retract, modify, watch, deffacts, reset, run. Terminal snippet shows a tiny session that: (reset), (watch facts), (assert ...), (run). End with Two Buttons meme again and a big FOLLOW badge and 'Try this in CLIPS REPL' CTA. Big bold follow/subscribe/try text with animated finger pressing a key.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Quick cheat-sheet: assert facts, use deftemplate/deffacts for structure and initial knowledge, watch to debug, run to fire rules, and reset to restart. Try it in the CLIPS REPL and follow for more deftemplate magic!
scenes.on_screen_text:
Cheat-sheet:
(deftemplate ...)
(deffacts initial-facts ...)
(assert (patient (name "A") (temp 39)))
(watch facts)
(run)
(reset)

Call-to-action:
Try this in CLIPS REPL — Follow for more
"Want to build an expert system? Meet CLIPS in 30s."

voice_timing.text: Want to build an expert system? Meet CLIPS — rule-based, object-oriented, procedural — in 30 seconds. Ready? Go!
CLIPS is multiparadigm: rules, objects, and procedures. Instead of tangled if/else, you write declarative rules that match facts.
CLIPS uses forward-chaining: start with facts, match rules, put activated rules on the agenda, then run to fire them and derive new facts.
Facts are chunks of info: a relation name with slots. Define their shape with deftemplate, then assert facts into the engine.
Use deffacts to assert a bundle of initial knowledge. Reset clears the environment and re-asserts those deffacts.
A rule has a header, LHS conditional elements to match facts, and RHS actions to execute when fired. Simple and declarative.
Pro tip: use (watch facts) to see facts being asserted or retracted. When an assert matches a rule pattern, that rule is activated and put on the agenda.
Hit (run) and CLIPS fires rules from the agenda. The RHS actions execute — printing, asserting, modifying, or retracting facts.
To change facts use (modify), to remove them use (retract). If facts contradict, don't panic — retract or modify, or reset to reload deffacts. Watch shows every change.
Use variables to capture values in patterns — e.g., ?name. Use multi-field variables like $?rest to match variable-length fields. Use anonymous/wildcard patterns when you don't need the value.
Remember: patterns matching facts activate rules onto the agenda. Run executes them in order (conflict resolution can reorder), producing new facts or actions — that's the CLIPS loop.

Quick cheat-sheet: assert facts, use deftemplate/deffacts for structure and initial knowledge, watch to debug, run to fire rules, and reset to restart. Try it in the CLIPS REPL and follow for more deftemplate magic!
